awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Geometry of Polynomials in Algorithms and Combinatorics
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphs and matrices are central objects in computer science. Two of the most successful paradigms for manipulating and optimizing over them are spectral methods, which study eigenvalues and eigenvectors, and semidefinite programming, which allows efficient optimization over certain convex sets defined by putting constraints on these eigenvalues. The goal of this proposal is to investigate a new technique for controlling eigenvalues which relies on tools from an area known as the geometry of polynomials. This alternate perspective was shown to be very powerful in recent work of the PI on Ramanujan expander graphs and the Kadison-Singer problem, and the PI believes that a more complete understanding of it will be fruitful both for theoretical computer science and for mathematics.

At a technical level, the  PI will focus on two points of contact between the geometry of polynomials and computer science: (A) The method of interlacing families of polynomials, a new analogue of the probabilistic method recently introduced by the PI and collaborators, based on studying random polynomials with real roots.  (B) Hyperbolic programming, a generalization of semidefinite programming which is intimately related to the polynomials appearing in (A).

More specifically, the proposal has the following goals: (i) Develop a more systematic and general understanding of (A) and use this to attack central linear-algebraic and combinatorial problems in TCS and applied math. (ii) Find efficient algorithms for producing the useful objects guaranteed to exist by (A), which currently require exponential time.  (iii) Explore the power of (B) as an algorithmic primitive in combinatorial optimization, in particular as an approach to graph partitioning problems, and understand whether it is actually more powerful than semidefinite programming.

The problems outlined in the proposal have the potential to impact various fields, such as signal processing, quantum computing, pseudorandomness, complexity theory, and operator theory. The subject is accessible to students of from diverse backgrounds across math and computer science, so this project uses to integrate research and education for both graduate and undergraduate students working between these fields.

por.por_cntn:
The main scientific activities supported by this award fall roughly into two related categories: geometry of polynomials and problems at the intersection of spectral graph theory, random matrix theory, and numerical linear algebra, which grew out of investigations in the first category.

In the first category, we studied certain special families of multivariate polynomials called real stable and hyperbolic polynomials. Our previous work had developed a technique relating these polynomials to eigenvalues of matrices, which occur throughout all branches of science and engineering.  Using this relationship, we were able to solve a number of fundamental problems in combinatorial linear algebra. Most notably (1) we gave the optimal bound for "paving" a matrix --- that is, breaking it into smaller matrices which have strictly smaller eigenvalues --- which strengthens our previous work on the Kadison-Singer problem. (2) we showed that such pavings can be found more efficiently by an algorithm (in subexponential time) than was previously known.

Hyperbolic polynomials are associated with an optimization paradigm called hyperbolic programming, which generalizes the widely used notion of semidefinite programming. A mystery in this area is whether this generalization is strict, or whether every hyperbolic program can actually be simulated by a semidefinite one. Using a randomized construction, we gave an example of a hyperbolic program with the property that any semidefinite program approximately simulating it must be much bigger in dimension. This provides evidence that hyperbolic programming is at least in one sense more expressive than semidefinite programming.

In the second category, our main achievement was the development of an algorithm which provably approximately diagonalizes an arbitrary matrix very efficiently --- in running time comparable to the time taken to simply multiply two matrices, which is likely to be the fastest achievable. This was a major improvement over the previously best provable algorithm, and is important since diagonalization is a primitive used in many branches of science and engineering. The analysis of the algorithm required proving an outstanding conjecture in numerical analysis stating that every matrix can be approximated by one whose eigenvalues are stable under further perturbation.

A widely used result in random matrix theory states that a sum of independent random matrices is likely to be concentrated around its mean. It was relatively mysterious what happens when the matrices are not independent. We proved that the concentration continues to hold when the matrices are sampled from a random walk on a graph, a situation which arises in many applications, establishing a conjecture in theoretical computer science.

Four graduate students received their PhDs doing research under this award. The above activities were accompanied by an extensive dissemination plan. The PI developed and taught a graduate course Geometry of Polynomials in 2015, whose lecture notes were used by researchers at other institutions.  The PI also co-organized two interdisciplinary research programs: the Quantitative Linear Algebra program at IPAM in Spring 2018, and the Geometry of Polynomials program at the Simons Institute in Spring 2019. The first program focused on connections between finite and infinite-dimensional linear algebra, and included researchers from operator algebras, Banach space theory, random matrix theory, and theoretical computer science. The PI gave a series of tutorials during this program on techniques related to expected characteristic polynomials, and organized a workshop on the topic. The second program hosted 40-50 researchers from theoretical computer science, optimization, probability, statistical physics, real algebraic geometry, and combinatorics. Besides being a productive semester with several new collaborations, the program produced high quality tutorial videos during the program's bootcamp, explaining the methods of this relatively new field in an accessible way.
